comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Exactly 130 years ago!  I find Garden Palace photos and info fascinating,  particularly because it had such a short existence.  If it was still around today it would be a useless eyesore. 

I wonder if that statue still exists somewhere?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Yes the statue is still in the Royal Botanical Gardens, near the Conservatorium Gate - No. 43 on this list - www.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/welcome/royal_botanic_garden/tours_...
" 43. Huntsman and Dogs This recently restored statue by the French sculptor A. Jacquemart is ‘imitation bronze’ - an iron casting on which copper has been deposited by electrolysis. It was cast by the Val d’Osne Company c. 1879. "
GoogleMapsSatelliteView

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: More about the statue - there's another casting in Victoria, and the story of what happened after the 1882 fire - museumvictoria.com.au/about/mv-blog/?tag=alfred%20jacquemart And a version in Beverley Hills, California, via the Chateau Thierry complete with WW1 shell holes - www.publicartinla.com/sculptures/hunter.html

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Location: Lawn 16, near Rose Garden Gate (previously called Conservation Gate) near site of Boston's Mill. This statue, by the French sculptor A. (Henry Alfred Marie) Jacquemart (1824-96) at the Rose Garden Gate, has been well-known to generations. And old photograph of the destroyed Garden Palace [ie. this photo] indicates that the statue was in the Gardens prior to the fire of 1882, after which it was relocated. 'Huntsman and Dogs' is 'imitation bronze' - and iron casting on which copper has been deposited by electrolysis. At the time of writing [1992] it had several rust patches and required conservation. Huntsman and Dogs was cast by the Val d'Osne Company and two copies were sold to Australia - one to the Sydney Gardens, the other to a family living in Melbourne at the corner of Burke Road and Myrniong Grove, Camberwell, which became a showpiece for tourists long before World War I. Their daughter married Mr. J. F. S. Allan, and the sculpture was transported to its present site at 330 Canterbury Road, at the corner of Wantirna Road, Ringwood. The Melbourne sculpture was at one stage exhibited in the sculpture court at the Nicholson Street entrance to the Exhibition Building, as photographed by Nicholas Caire in 1881. [ handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/68922 ] Source: Edwin Wilson, The Wishing Tree (Sydney, Kangaroo Press in association with the Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney, 1992), p. 96. Note that the Royal Botanic Gardens historian Edwin Wilson gives a differing account of the Melbourne statue to that related in the MuseumVictoria blog.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Ah, this is interesting. The Melbourne sculpture, a 'magnificent bronze garden statue, "Huntsman and Dogs," by A. Jacquemart', was listed for sale at auction among the contents of the estate of the late Hon Duncan E. McBryde [ adb.anu.edu.au/biography/mcbryde-duncan-elphinstone-7296 ], "Kamesburgh," Wallace Avenue, Toorak on Friday, 6 May 1921 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/1754002 Both the book and the blog look like they contain errors.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: A later photo showing the Sydney sculpture in a different location: Botanical Gardens, Sydney [showing Huntsman and Dogs sculpture] ca. 1900-1910 - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=413771

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Ah-ha, here's Wilsons owner. The 'beautiful bronze statue, Huntsman and Dogs, by A. Jacquemart, which is standing in the grounds of Myrniong' was listed for sale at auction in the estate of the late William Thomas Cale on Saturday, 14 September 1940. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/608953 So Wilson was correct, but had not realised there was a previous owner.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Great stuff!  It is confusing when there are two (or more) statues.  As I understand it, the statue in this photo was part of the exhibit of the Val d'Osne Co. at the 1879 Sydney Exhibition;  went to Melbourne for the 1880 Exhibition,  and was bought by the NSW Government for 180 Pounds in 1881.    Or did it not go to Melbourne?

I left a courtesy note on the blog so there may be more information to come.  It is awaiting moderation and schpellin kurexshun.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hmm, that's possible. But my thinking is that the NSW Government bought the copy on display at the Sydney exhibition, while a private buyer (most likely McBryde) bought the copy on display at the Melbourne exhibition.

[I left several comments on the blog. I realised later I should have just left a link to our discussion here - but one gets excited doing research!]
